text.p: These are the stories making headlines in the Namibian newspapers on Wednesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- In a tense stand-off at Oshakati, ex-combatants protesting for jobs held four regional councillors hostage for nearly five hours at the Swapo head office yesterday afternoon.
- With two agreements on co-operation in his pocket, Congolese president Laurent Kabila concluded his visit to Namibia.

- The National Society for Human Rights has called for an investigation to look into reports of human rights violations on the Angola-Namibia border allegedly perpetrated by members of the Namibian defence force.
- A regional coordinator of SWAPO and his personnel are being held hostage by 600 former fighters, who are protesting to demand jobs, at the SWAPO offices in Oshakati.

- Congolese president Laurent Kabila left Namibia after his first official state-visit since taking power in former Zaire in May with two bilateral agreements having been signed between Namibia and the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
